awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Pathway to Commercialization at Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs)
awd_abstract_narration:
Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) exert an outsized influence on the production of Black STEM majors, relative to Predominantly White Institutions (PWIs), yet they often lack the financial resources and infrastructure needed to support technology commercialization.  Development of technology transfer resources at HBCUs could directly impact a significant proportion of African American scientists and engineers, and the African American tech-entrepreneurial pipeline. This project seeks to explore the technology and technology transfer infrastructure at a subset of HBCUs with Computer Science and Engineering Departments. It will investigate PWIs with consortium models in their approach to technology transfer offices in an effort to understand the feasibility of HBCUs to establish similar consortium models. Further, it will identify best practices among consortium models that hold the most promise for the HBCU environment.


The Pathways to Commercialization for HBCUs project seeks to explore the technology and technology transfer infrastructure at a subset of ABET-accredited HBCUs and CISE-funded HBCUs. The project will investigate PWIs with consortium models in their approach to technology transfer offices in an effort to understand the feasibility of HBCUs to establish similar consortium models. Customer discovery will be conducted to identify both assets and pain points from technology commercialization administrators and faculty at the participating HBCUs. Additional discovery will be conducted with PWIs that have some elements of their TTO functions centralized. The work will be guided by the following research questions: 1) What is the current capacity of HBCUs to perform technology transfer; 2) To what extent do HBCUs view technology commercialization as a business opportunity; 3) What are the differences in faculty incentives for technology commercialization at research intensive research institutions vs HBCUs; and 4) Can a subset of potential shared activities be identified to improve technology commercialization at HBCUs? The goal of the customer discovery is to answer those questions. In particular, the project aims to identify best practices among consortium models that hold the most promise for the HBCU environment. A virtual convening will be held to discuss findings from the customer discovery, conduct design thinking sessions, and adopt a set of recommendations for implementing best practices.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to assess and strengthen the technology transfer capacity of Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) through a customer discovery initiative. The study explored existing Technology Transfer Office (TTO) functions, identified best practices and challenges, and assessed the feasibility of consortium models for HBCUs. Key activities included customer discovery with HBCUs and commercialization entities, engagement with national organizations, and development of strategic partnerships to enhance HBCU participation in technology transfer. Findings indicate that while some HBCUs have early-stage technology transfer engagement, challenges remain in commercialization, licensing, and scaling innovation. 

Key Outcomes

  • Customer Discovery & Institutional Engagement:
    • Conducted outreach to five ABET-accredited and/or NSF CISE-funded HBCUs and Kentucky Commercialization Ventures (KVC).
    • Identified additional HBCU personnel for customer discovery interviews and landscape mapping.
    • Engaged HBCU staff and leaders through the various forums such as AUTM, UIDP HBCU Engage, and the UNCF Meeting of the Minds event to assess commercialization interests and needs.
  • Assessment of Technology Transfer Readiness:
    • HBCUs scored high in early-stage activities (technology scouting: 3.0; invention disclosures: 3.0) but lower in commercialization readiness (finding licensing partners: 1.3; commercialization assessment: 1.7).
    • These findings highlight the need for structured support to improve later-stage commercialization activities.
  • Strategic Partnerships & National Engagement:
    • Collaborated with Kentucky State University to assess the effectiveness of the KVC model.
    • Leveraged the AUTM Emerging Research Institutions (ERI) Program to provide technology transfer training and mentorship to HBCUs.
    • The project leadership presented at various forums, engaged HBCU leadership at different venues, and were instrumental in helping to guide several discussions and initiatives.
  • Professional Development Impact:
    • A JSU student, who was supported by the project, participated in the AUTM Fellowship program, attending AUTM University, the Annual Meeting, and the Eastern Region Meeting.
    • A Howard University graduate student served as a moderator and panelist at national innovation conferences, including the USPTO and BEYA events.
    • A project-affiliated student was hired as Program Director for Jackson State University’s Center for Innovation and Entrepreneurship and completed the Mid-South I-Corps train-the-trainer workshop.

Broader Impacts

This project contributes to increasing diversity in technology transfer by actively engaging HBCUs in the national innovation ecosystem. By mapping existing commercialization activities and identifying gaps, the project provides a foundation for scaling technology transfer capacity at institutions that historically have had limited engagement in this space. The initiative also fosters industry and government partnerships that will support sustainable innovation pipelines for HBCUs.

Key contributions include:

  • Strengthening HBCU Research Commercialization: The project’s findings will inform targeted capacity-building initiatives to enhance technology transfer at HBCUs.
  • National-Level Collaboration: Engagement with AUTM, USPTO, UIDP, and other organizations ensures continued opportunities for HBCUs in commercialization and innovation policy discussions.
  • Workforce Development: The project provided direct professional development opportunities for students and faculty, equipping them with commercialization expertise that will support long-term institutional success.

Intellectual Merit

This research provides empirical insights into the state of technology transfer at HBCUs, identifying strengths and barriers to commercialization. The self-assessment data from participating institutions establish a baseline for evaluating the effectiveness of future interventions. Findings from this project contribute to the broader field of university-based commercialization by:

  • Mapping technology transfer functions in underrepresented institutional settings.
  • Evaluating models, such as Kentucky Commercialization Ventures, that may be replicable at HBCUs.
  • Providing actionable recommendations for strengthening innovation infrastructure in resource-constrained environments.

The study also informs national technology transfer strategies by highlighting the specific needs of HBCUs and presenting evidence-based recommendations for policymakers, funding agencies, and industry partners.

Conclusion

This project has made significant progress in assessing and enhancing the role of HBCUs in technology transfer. By engaging key stakeholders, mapping institutional challenges, and forming strategic partnerships, it has laid the groundwork for long-term improvements in commercialization pathways. The project team will continue to leverage insights from this study to create commercialization training workshops, industry engagement initiatives, and policy recommendations to strengthen HBCU TTOs.

 


Last Modified: 02/13/2025
Modified by: Almesha L Campbell
por.por_txt_cntn:
This project aimed to assess and strengthen the technology transfer capacity of Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) through a customer discovery initiative. The study explored existing Technology Transfer Office (TTO) functions, identified best practices and challenges, and assessed the feasibility of consortium models for HBCUs. Key activities included customer discovery with HBCUs and commercialization entities, engagement with national organizations, and development of strategic partnerships to enhance HBCU participation in technology transfer. Findings indicate that while some HBCUs have early-stage technology transfer engagement, challenges remain in commercialization, licensing, and scaling innovation.


Key Outcomes

Customer Discovery & Institutional Engagement: 

Conducted outreach to five ABET-accredited and/or NSF CISE-funded HBCUs and Kentucky Commercialization Ventures (KVC).
Identified additional HBCU personnel for customer discovery interviews and landscape mapping.
Engaged HBCU staff and leaders through the various forums such as AUTM, UIDP HBCU Engage, and the UNCF Meeting of the Minds event to assess commercialization interests and needs.


Assessment of Technology Transfer Readiness: 

HBCUs scored high in early-stage activities (technology scouting: 3.0; invention disclosures: 3.0) but lower in commercialization readiness (finding licensing partners: 1.3; commercialization assessment: 1.7).
These findings highlight the need for structured support to improve later-stage commercialization activities.


Strategic Partnerships & National Engagement: 

Collaborated with Kentucky State University to assess the effectiveness of the KVC model.
Leveraged the AUTM Emerging Research Institutions (ERI) Program to provide technology transfer training and mentorship to HBCUs.
The project leadership presented at various forums, engaged HBCU leadership at different venues, and were instrumental in helping to guide several discussions and initiatives.


Professional Development Impact: 

A JSU student, who was supported by the project, participated in the AUTM Fellowship program, attending AUTM University, the Annual Meeting, and the Eastern Region Meeting.
A Howard University graduate student served as a moderator and panelist at national innovation conferences, including the USPTO and BEYA events.
A project-affiliated student was hired as Program Director for Jackson State Universitys Center for Innovation and Entrepreneurship and completed the Mid-South I-Corps train-the-trainer workshop.





Broader Impacts


This project contributes to increasing diversity in technology transfer by actively engaging HBCUs in the national innovation ecosystem. By mapping existing commercialization activities and identifying gaps, the project provides a foundation for scaling technology transfer capacity at institutions that historically have had limited engagement in this space. The initiative also fosters industry and government partnerships that will support sustainable innovation pipelines for HBCUs.


Key contributions include:

Strengthening HBCU Research Commercialization:The projects findings will inform targeted capacity-building initiatives to enhance technology transfer at HBCUs.
National-Level Collaboration:Engagement with AUTM, USPTO, UIDP, and other organizations ensures continued opportunities for HBCUs in commercialization and innovation policy discussions.
Workforce Development:The project provided direct professional development opportunities for students and faculty, equipping them with commercialization expertise that will support long-term institutional success.



Intellectual Merit


This research provides empirical insights into the state of technology transfer at HBCUs, identifying strengths and barriers to commercialization. The self-assessment data from participating institutions establish a baseline for evaluating the effectiveness of future interventions. Findings from this project contribute to the broader field of university-based commercialization by:

Mapping technology transfer functions in underrepresented institutional settings.
Evaluating models, such as Kentucky Commercialization Ventures, that may be replicable at HBCUs.
Providing actionable recommendations for strengthening innovation infrastructure in resource-constrained environments.



The study also informs national technology transfer strategies by highlighting the specific needs of HBCUs and presenting evidence-based recommendations for policymakers, funding agencies, and industry partners.


Conclusion


This project has made significant progress in assessing and enhancing the role of HBCUs in technology transfer. By engaging key stakeholders, mapping institutional challenges, and forming strategic partnerships, it has laid the groundwork for long-term improvements in commercialization pathways. The project team will continue to leverage insights from this study to create commercialization training workshops, industry engagement initiatives, and policy recommendations to strengthen HBCU TTOs.
